messageBody:
I usually like to have two sets of unit tests per class.
1° Construction tests :
Either testing the constructor or the factory for different construction types
 
2°. Behavior tests :
Using the constructed instances, I validate their behaviors.
 
Say I'have a class A, Then make two classes in the subpackage test :
    _ test.TestCreateA
    _ test.TestA
 
the class test.TestALL (I'm no using the JUnit automatic tests discoveryfeature), the contains the following static method :
    public static TestSuite suite()
    {
        TestSuite suite = new TestSuite()
            suite.addTest(TestCreateA.suite());
            suite.addTest(TestA.suite());
 
        return suite;
    }
 
I usually manage to discover that I've a construction problem when I get Error/Failures all over my tests (I currently do :-D ironically).
 
 
Thomas,
 
 
 
----- Original Message -----
From: kelso7104
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 6:36 PM
Subject: [junit] Testing initial conditions

I have a class that calls initialize() from within the constructor. 

Would it be better to:
1) write a unit test that validates the initial conditions, or
2) have the production class validate its own initial conditions and
unit test that the class handles invalid initial conditions?
